quoteFirst: At half-past 2 this morning, the landing-master’s bell was rung on board of the Tender; and at a
quoteLast: , the writer landed with fifteen masons, nine mill-wrights and joiners, two blacksmiths, and ten seamen, in all thirty-six, with their respective foremen. The low-water work continued two hours and a half, when those employed at the Beacon were left as usual to continue their operations.
title:
An Account of the Bell Rock Light-House
Including the Details of the Erection and Peculiar Structure of That Edifice; to Which Is Prefixed a Historical View of the Institution and Progress of the Northern Light-Houses
author: Stevenson, Robert, 1772-1850

quoteFirst: Set off in great haste to dine with the Comtesse de R., on an invitation of a week's standing. Arrive at about a
quoteLast: , and find in the drawing-room some dirty linen and no fire. While a waiting-woman takes away one, a valet lights up the other. Three small sticks in a deep bed of ashes give no great expectation of heat. By the smoke, however, all doubts are removed respecting the existence of fire. To expel the smoke, a window is opened, and, the day being cold, I have the benefit of as fresh air as can reasonably be expected in so large a city.
title: Gouverneur Morris
author: Roosevelt, Theodore, 1858-1919

quoteFirst: On January 1, 1874, ‘rouse’ sounded soon after midnight, and the parade was at 1.20 in the morning. The left wing, consisting of four companies (17 officers and 352 men), landed in surf boats, the first company reaching the shore at a
quoteLast: , the fourth company in about a quarter of an hour afterwards. The whole disembarkation occupied about forty minutes, and elicited the warm approval of the Brigadier, Sir Archibald Alison.

quoteFirst: A sail was seen steering south at twenty minutes past two o’clock, and the _Constitution_ cleared for action, but the vessel passed on, and soon disappeared. At daylight the lieutenant in charge of the wreck hailed to say she had four feet of water in her hold and appeared to be in danger of sinking, but she kept afloat until afternoon, when she was set on fire, and at
quoteLast: , on August 21, 1812, the flames reached her magazine and she was blown to pieces. “A huge column of smoke arose and stood for a long time in the calm atmosphere, and then slowly crumbled to pieces, revealing only a few shattered planks to tell where the proud vessel had sunk.
title: The history of our Navy from its origin to the present day, 1775-1897, vol. 2 (of 4)

quoteFirst: He might, however, have spared a portion of it, and that portion, as we shall see later, would have been most obviously Erlon's corps--the First. Rather more than an hour later, at about a
quoteLast: , when Napoleon had just joined battle with the Prussians, he got a note from Ney informing him that the left wing was meeting with considerable resistance, and could hardly abandon the place where it was engaged before Quatre Bras to come up against the Prussian flank at Ligny.

quoteFirst: _Sunday, 28._--At a
quoteLast: we were again on the water, and as we could perceive no current setting into this bay, we made the best of our way to the point that bore South from us yesterday afternoon. quoteFirst: Three o'clock, and the express leaves Euston Square for Scotland at a quarter past. The heat in the station is very great, the noise almost deafening; huge engines are pouring out volumes of steam, the shrill whistle sounds, porters are hurrying to and fro. The
quoteLast: train is a great favorite--more people travel by that than by any other--and the platform is crowded by ladies, children, tourists, commercial gentlemen. There are very few of the humbler class. Ten minutes past three. The passengers are taking their places.
title:

quoteLast: and about 3.30 asked us if we wished to be taken off. This steamer proved to be the s.s. _Orn_ (Captain Rewne). He manoeuvred and lowered a boat and took us aboard about 4.15 p.m.
